message_1: Suppose the complex function $f(z) = \sum_{n=0}^\infty z^n$ is defined on the open unit disk $D = \{z \in \mathbb{C} : |z| < 1\}$. If we define $g(z)$ as the analytic continuation of $f(z)$ to the set $\mathbb{C} \backslash \{1\}$, what is the value of $g(2)$?
message_2:
The function $f(z) = \sum_{n=0}^\infty z^n$ is the geometric series, which converges on the open unit disk $D = \{z \in \mathbb{C} : |z| < 1\}$. The sum of the geometric series is given by the formula:

$f(z) = \frac{1}{1-z}$, for $|z| < 1$.

Now, we want to find the analytic continuation of $f(z)$ to the set $\mathbb{C} \backslash \{1\}$. The function $g(z) = \frac{1}{1-z}$ is already analytic on $\mathbb{C} \backslash \{1\}$, so it serves as the analytic continuation of $f(z)$.

To find the value of $g(2)$, we simply plug in $z = 2$ into the expression for $g(z)$:

$g(2) = \frac{1}{1-2} = \frac{1}{-1} = -1$.

So, the value of $g(2)$ is $-1$.
